It always bugged me how words such as "Arthropods" and "Arthropoda" are used. They both come from the plural of "Arthropod" and we tend to use them in different situations.....  That applies with Annelids and Annelida, Chordata and Chordates, Nematoda and Nematodes and basically most phyla.

Everything should be okay, as long as the animal eaten is treated well before consumption and as long as if it's edible (obviously).   An animal's cuteness or beauty should not be a reason not to consume it. Though I can see why eating a butterfly could be nonsensical. But in some regions people eat grasshoppers though. And where I live we eat lots of cute cows, goats, pigs and birds. I find it silly when people say they don't like it when beautiful animals are eaten, as if it were only okay when an animal is "ugly".  Also I doubt a butterfly is beautiful for a reason. After all beauty is a human concept and not an inherent quality created by nature.

You are trying to say that unrelated - consecutive - complementary - accidental changes you call " beneficial mutations" that have to be selected account for the millions of uniform symmetrical differences of every genus there is. You need to understand that there is an immune system and homeostasis that resists those kinds of changes, which never really happen, to begin with. A single beneficial mutation, entirely free of side effects is extremely rare while multiple beneficial changes that are complementary to previous changes and the rest of the genome are entirely out of the question, especially when you need millions or even billions of such changes for evolution to ever occur, which is a mathematical absurdity.

Key terms mentioned in this video:  Annelids Segmentation Arthropods Coelem Cephalothorax Crustacea  Insect (Population compared to other organisms)   Summary of this video:   While humans and chordates may be pretty complex species, we could not have been so mighty without insects. On a side note, insects topple all other organisms combined. That being said, we must learn about these insects to get a better understanding of ourselves.   Across the Disciplines:   Angiosperms ("flowering plants") required the use of insects to evolve.

pretty spot on, but, in partial metamorphosis often a key difference between adults and nymphs is that the nymphs always lacks wings, while the adults may have them (although in some cases the wings are not suited for flight.)  Examples include mantids, stick and leaf insects, and cicadas, to name a few. So, the difference between partially metamorphosing nymphs and adults is not just limited to size.

Hank saying "millipedes don't have a thousand legs but centipedes can have a hundred "or thereabouts. Not a direct quote. I've heard a million times, but I like to look at it this way. Millipedes have a feet spacing that's approx  a millimeter (Not really but it kind of appears so.) apart. Centipedes have a feet spacing approx a centimeter (Again not really but close) apart. So spacing and not the number of legs, I think is what it means.

Nematodes are related to arthropods and annelids are related to molluscs, so they aren't really "cousins". For instance, new genetic studies have been yielding evidence to suggest that ectdysozoans are more related to each other then even very similar looking none cuticle bearing/shedding organisms. In fact, arthropods have no lungs. They use a complex system of airways that pump air through spiracles, little dots on the side of the abdomen, unless they are a marine, aquatic, or semi-aquatic, where they would have gills, or both gills and airways. In the Carboniferous period, like in the video, would have more oxygen content than today's concentration, and with the decreasing oxygen quality, giant insects like Meganeura, would have a more difficult time breathing with its large oxygen...

By hexapods, this refers to merely having 6 legs, because some arthropods are not classified as insects but have 6 legs. This is the class of Entognatha. These are not insects because some have only simple or no eyes.
NOT ALL CENTIPEDES ARE POISONOUS. So relax.
Like in the video, the Greeks called arachnids "arm lips" due to their leg-like pedipalps, which are also regarded as mouth parts.
The term hermaphrodite is approprite when used in the context of biology. The term means that all indivisuals in the species has male and female sexual reproductive organs.
Cheliceriformes refers to the mouth parts of arachnids which includes spiders, scorpions, pseudoscorpions, windscorpions whipscorpions, tailless whipscorpions, and ticks and mites called chelicerae.

Actually, I just looked it up, and they're not that closely related to Protists. I was right in saying that they're segmented, though.

The tardigrade is not an insect at all, nor is it even an arthropod. Tardigrada is its own phylum (in the same way that arthropods and chordates are phyla). It is much smaller than virtually all arthropods and a bit simpler, but it does exhibit segmentation if I remember correctly. It may be the closest relative in the Animal kingdom to the non-animal Protists, but we don't know for sure. I hope that's informative :)
